abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: Hemi-spatial neglect in humans is a common aftermath of stroke damage to subcortical and cortical brain structures, including the dorsocaudal temporal cortex. In macaques, reversible inactivation of some homologous brain structures (e.g. midbrain, prefrontal cortex) in selective attention tasks lead to behavioral symptoms of neglect, but as yet there is no evidence linking temporal cortex to neglect. To identify the neurological basis of neglect in macaques, we combined fMRI during attention tasks with pharmacologic suppression of midbrain activity. Functional mapping of brain areas during midbrain-induced neglect revealed a profound suppression of attention-related modulation in a small region (aFST/IPa) on the floor of the superior temporal sulcus. The same aFST/IPa region was also affected during neglect induced by inactivation of the prefrontal cortex. These results identify for the first time a region in the temporal cortex of macaque that is selectively affected during neglect induced by both subcortical and cortical inactivation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In humans, hemi-spatial neglect is a common consequence of stroke damage to a range of cortical and subcortical structures (Corbetta and Shulman, 2011; Halligan et al., 2003; Heilman et al., 2000; Karnath and Rorden, 2012; Mesulam, 1981; Milner and McIntosh, 2005; Parton et al., 2004), and is defined as a behavioral syndrome characterized by failures to orient, detect or respond to stimuli in the visual field opposite to the brain lesion in the absence of sensory processing or motor deficits (Heilman et al., 1994; Rees et al., 2000). As such, hemi-spatial neglect is most closely associated with a disruption of attention-related mechanisms, that have been studied extensively in both humans and monkeys. Although neglect is diagnosed using clinical tests, performance deficits in attention-related paradigms such as the Posner cuing tasks are most sensitive during both acute and chronic stages (Rengachary et al., 2009).

The anatomy of spatial neglect is complex and entails the interaction between multiple brain systems. Spatial neglect is most commonly associated with damage to the inferior parietal and frontal cortices that have long been implicated in neglect (Bender and Butter, 1987; Critchley, 1953; Heilman and Valenstein, 1972; Husain and Kennard, 1996; Mort, 2003; Umarova et al., 2011; Verdon et al., 2010). At the same time, damage to subcortical structures in the telencephalon (e.g. striatum), thalamus (e.g. pulvinar) and midbrain (e.g. superior colliculus, SC) can lead to highly overlapping symptoms (Karnath et al., 2002; Snow et al., 2009; Weddell, 2004). Recent work in humans has placed emphasis on the temporal cortex, with meta-analysis suggesting that its contribution to spatial neglect has been previously under-appreciated (Karnath et al., 2001). In particular, the dorsocaudal temporal cortex regions of the superior temporal gyrus (STG) and temporo-parietal junction (TPJ) have been hypothesized to play a particularly important role in spatial neglect (Chechlacz et al., 2010; Corbetta and Shulman, 2002; Ellison, 2004; Friedrich et al., 1998; Hillis, 2005; Karnath, 2004; Meister et al., 2006; Thiebaut de Schotten et al., 2005). These temporal cortical regions are also part of the functional network with frontal and parietal areas implicated in spatial attention in humans (Corbetta et al., 2005).

Understanding the brain mechanisms underlying spatial neglect requires systematic testing of hypotheses in animal models such as the macaque, whose perceptual specializations are similar to those in humans (Orban et al., 2004). Attention-related deficits associated with visual neglect in humans have been demonstrated in the macaque following reversible inactivation of several homologous brain structures, such as the SC, pulvinar, parietal cortex (lateral intraparietal area, LIP) and prefrontal cortex (frontal eye fields, FEF) (Gregoriou et al., 2014; Lovejoy and Krauzlis, 2010; Monosov et al., 2011; Petersen et al., 1987; Wardak et al., 2004). However, the temporal cortical regions functionally linked to spatial neglect are yet to be identified in monkeys (Patel et al., 2015).

To determine brain regions functionally associated with spatial neglect in monkeys, we performed fMRI before and during midbrain-induced neglect in two monkeys performing visual selective attention tasks. We chose reversible inactivation of midbrain SC to induce spatial neglect, because inactivation of this structure leads to robust attention-related deficits, which are a hallmark of neglect (Lovejoy and Krauzlis, 2010; Zénon and Krauzlis, 2012). The broad coverage of fMRI provides a means to compare attention-related modulation throughout the brain under normal behavior (“control”) and following SC inactivation (“neglect”) to identify brain regions functionally affected during the induced neglect phenomenon.

Our results show that, across the brain, the strongest unilateral suppression of attention-related modulation during midbrain-induced neglect was found in a circumscribed region (aFST/IPa) of the mid-STS cortex. Smaller unilateral reductions in modulation were observed in other regions of the cortex including FEF and part of area TPO. Surprisingly, neglect induced by inactivation of the prefrontal cortex also affected the same aFST/IPa region and additional experiments demonstrated that the reduction in attention-related modulation of the aFST/IPa region during neglect was not contingent on the stimulus feature used in the attention tasks. These findings identify for the first time a region in the mid-STS cortex of macaque that is linked to hemi-spatial neglect and is a functional component of both midbrain and prefrontal circuits associated with selective attention.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Two adult macaques were scanned using BOLD fMRI across repeated sessions while performing three attention tasks. During some sessions, visual neglect was induced through inactivation of the superior colliculus using injection of muscimol, whereas during other sessions there was either no injection or the injection of a saline control. During fMRI data collection, the Baseline, Ignore and Attend tasks were presented in blocks (Fig. 1A-D; See Methods). In all three tasks, the color of the central cue indicated the relevant stimulus to be monitored for change detection. The monkeys maintained strict central fixation and reported the relevant changes detected by releasing a joystick. In Baseline task, monkeys monitored the fixation stimulus to detect a possible luminance change. The Ignore task was similar to the Baseline task but included peripheral visual stimuli that could change motion direction but were entirely task irrelevant. In the Attend task, monkeys monitored the same peripheral visual stimuli to detect possible changes in motion direction. Both monkeys performed the three attention tasks reliably, obtaining hit rates for relevant changes that were significantly higher than false alarm rates on both trials with task-irrelevant changes and catch trials containing no changes (Chi-square proportion test; p<0.0001).

sec.title: Neglect induced by the suppression of midbrain activity
sec.p: Spatial neglect was induced by reversible inactivation of the superior colliculus (SC). Specifically, we injected 0.3 – 0.5 μl of muscimol into the deep layers of SC (left SC in monkey #1 and right SC in monkey #2). In addition to the neglect effects, described below, inactivation affected the metrics of saccadic eye movements, including changes in latency and peak eye velocity. These changes were a useful means to monitor the location and duration of the muscimol effects on SC activity, as the saccadic effects were retinotopic and affected only portions of the visual field (Fig. 1E). By mapping the changes in saccade metrics caused by muscimol 30 minutes following the end of injection, we were able to identify the specific portion of the visual field affected in each session (blue region in Figure 1E) and confirm that the visual stimulus in the attention tasks fully overlapped with the affected visual field (see Figure 1E, stimuli depicted as white circles). Following the confirmation of SC inactivation, monkeys were placed in the scanner for imaging in three attention tasks, which were always performed while the animal maintained strict central fixation. The effectiveness of muscimol was checked at the end of each imaging run (every 8 minutes) by having the monkeys perform a pair of visually guided saccade into and out of the affected visual field location, as illustrated for a sample session (Figure 1E, bottom); the difference in latencies confirmed that the SC remained inactivated for the full duration of the imaging runs in the experimental session. For every imaging session, the latencies of saccades to targets into the affected field were significantly longer than the latencies of saccades to targets in the unaffected visual field (Wilcoxon rank sum test; p<0.05).

Superior colliculus inactivation disrupted detection performance in the Attend task for contralateral stimulus changes in both monkeys, in agreement with previous findings (Lovejoy and Krauzlis, 2017; 2010; Zénon and Krauzlis, 2012). To quantify these deficits, we compared the hit rate for motion-direction changes in the contralateral visual field versus the ipsilateral visual field for each session (Fig. 1F). During SC inactivation (blue symbols), all but one session showed a significant reduction in hit rate for motion-direction changes for the stimulus in the affected contralateral visual field compared to the stimulus in the unaffected ipsilateral visual field (Chi-square proportion test; p<0.05). For the no-injection and saline sessions (orange and black symbols), we did not find a significant difference in hit rates between the contralateral and ipsilateral visual fields (Chi-square proportion test; p<0.05). These results show that SC inactivation caused deficits in the detection of contralateral stimulus-change events, akin to the deficits in the detection of contralateral targets observed in hemi-spatial neglect (Corbetta et al., 2005; Rengachary et al., 2009). We refer to the deficits in the Attend task during SC inactivation as midbrain-induced neglect.

Overall, we collected 18 sessions with muscimol injection (880 blocks each for both the Ignore and Attend tasks in monkey #1, 912 blocks each for monkey #2), 16 no-injection sessions (920 blocks each for both the Ignore and Attend tasks in monkey #1, 1008 blocks each for monkey #2), and 8 saline sessions in Monkey # 1 (928 blocks each for both the Ignore and Attend tasks). Throughout the manuscript, we refer to the no-injection sessions as “control” and the muscimol sessions as “neglect”.

sec.title: Midbrain-induced neglect linked to aFST/IPa region in the mid-STS cortex
sec.p: Taking advantage of the broad coverage of fMRI, we measured the attention-related modulation of brain activity with and without midbrain-induced neglect. Comparing these conditions allowed us to identify the brain regions that were selectively affected during neglect. Attention-related modulation was defined as the contrast between the Attend and Ignore tasks. To minimize the contribution of saccadic eye movements, rewards and joystick-related movements, regressors for these variables were included as part of the general linear model (see Methods). We further excluded voxels that mapped onto foveal locations, based on a separate retinotopic mapping experiment (see Methods), because these might be subject to the very small stimulus differences at the fovea in the two conditions (black versus red cue; Fig. 1B, C). The rationale for this approach and a full map of attention-related modulation including foveal voxels in the same attention tasks and animals were described in a previous study (Bogadhi et al., 2018).

In the absence of SC inactivation during control sessions, the Attend blocks elicited higher BOLD responses in several brain areas compared to the Ignore blocks. For each monkey, the t-score maps showing this attention-related modulation (Bonferroni corrected; p < 0.05) were projected onto partially inflated cortical surface of the hemisphere ipsilateral to the pending SC inactivation (Fig. 2A, 2C, see Fig. S1 for contralateral hemispheres). Consistent with previous work (Caspari et al., 2015; Stemmann and Freiwald, 2016), we found significant modulation in areas MT, MST, FST, PGa, IPa and parts of TEO and TPO of the superior temporal sulcus, areas LIPd, LIPv and area PEa of the intraparietal sulcus, and areas 45b, 8Bs, 8Ad, 8Av, 46d, 46v of the frontal cortex (Fig. 2A, 2C).

sec.p: Following midbrain-induced neglect, certain cortical subregions of the injected hemisphere showed reduced attention-related modulation (Fig. 2B, 2D). In both monkeys, the reduction was strongest in a portion of the mid-STS. In monkey #2 there was no significant reduction in attention-related modulation outside of this region (Fig. 2D), whereas in monkey #1, weaker but statistically significant reductions were also observed in IPS and frontal cortex (Fig. 2B). There was no evidence of suppressed attention-related modulation in the contralateral hemisphere, although there was some evidence of enhanced attention-related modulation (see Supplementary Fig. S1, discussed further below).

To visualize the suppression in attention-related modulation across the cortex during neglect, we performed a voxel-wise ANOVA with two factors and two levels each – Covert attention (Attend and Ignore conditions) and Neglect (control and neglect sessions). The ANOVA was based on the Attend and Ignore BOLD measurements in the control and neglect sessions (see Methods), with the interaction term capturing the attention-related deficits associated with neglect. This analysis was similar to the ANOVA analysis used in a previous fMRI study in humans investigating the neural basis and recovery of spatial attention deficits in neglect (Corbetta et al., 2005).

Hemi-neglect is characterized by behavioral deficits contralateral to injury or inactivation of SC as demonstrated in this study (Fig. 1F). Thus, in the present experiments, the cortical areas most directly linked to midbrain-induced neglect would be ipsilateral to the injection site and show a unilateral suppression of BOLD attention-related modulation during neglect. To identify the brain regions whose attention-related modulation was suppressed unilaterally during neglect, we overlaid the interaction term F-statistic from the voxel-wise ANOVA onto partially inflated cortical surfaces of the ipsilateral hemispheres in both monkeys (Fig. 3A, 3B). The negative sign of the F-statistic reflects decrease in modulation during neglect (see Methods).

sec.p: The inflated maps of F-statistic in both monkeys show one contiguous patch of blue in the mid-STS cortex (Fig. 3A, 3B). The blue region shows voxels strongly affected in the aFST/IPa region during neglect (Monkey #1: F (1,24971) = -165.58;Monkey #2: F (1, 26645) = -111.59). The degrees of freedom (Monkey #1: 24971; Monkey #2: 26645) indicate the BOLD measurements during the Attend and Ignore blocks across all the control and neglect sessions. A magnified view of the STS shows a large swathe of blue in the mid-STS region that reflects the spatial extent of the reduction in attention-related modulation during neglect (Fig. 3C, 3D). The affected voxels in the mid-STS spanned two anatomical areas – anterior FST and posterior IPa in both monkeys (Fig. 3C, 3D), and hence we refer to this region as aFST/IPa.

We localized the effect in aFST/IPa region to the lower part of the fundus in STS in both monkeys at the same anterior-posterior location as shown in coronal slices (Fig. 3E, 3F). We observed a significant increase in modulation on the contralateral side during neglect in both monkeys (Monkey #1: F (1,24971) = 29.83; Monkey #2: F (1, 26645) = 44.15). The unilateral suppression of modulation in the aFST/IPa region (Fig. 3E, 3F) combined with the lateralized behavioral deficits observed during neglect (Fig. 1F) demonstrates a strong link between aFST/IPa region and midbrain-induced neglect.

Control analyses accounting for other factors such as saccadic eye movements, rewards, and joystick related movements (see Supplemental Info, Fig. S2), as well as comparisons with saline injection controls (see Supplemental Info, Fig. S3) further confirm and strengthen our finding that the aFST/IPa region in mid-STS cortex was strongly linked to midbrain-induced neglect.

sec.title: Temporal and frontal cortical regions affected during midbrain-induced neglect
sec.p: The aFST/IPa region ipsilateral to SC inactivation was the most affected brain region during neglect both in terms of size and spatial extent of the effect, and hence pops out in the inflated maps of the voxel-wise analysis (blue region in Fig. 3). In comparison, the effect in ipsilateral frontal cortex (Monkey #1: F (1,24971) = -38.07; Monkey #2: F (1, 26645) = -40.51) and MT (Monkey #1: F (1,24971) = -33.71; Monkey #2: F (1, 26645) = -50.87) was significant but weaker in spatial extent and size, and hence was not easily seen in the inflated maps of the voxel-wise analysis (Fig. 3). To quantify the effect on attention-related modulation during midbrain-induced neglect in different cortical regions, we performed regions of interest (ROIs) analysis and identified the brain regions that showed unilateral reduction in attention-related modulation, consistent with the lateralized behavioral deficits observed during neglect (Fig. 1F).

Regions of interest (ROIs) were defined as 2mm-radius spheres centered on the local maxima of the attention-related modulation map from the control sessions; we compared the modulation in these ROIs between the control and neglect sessions. Ipsilateral ROIs were defined based on the modulation maps shown in Fig. 2A, 2C and contralateral ROIs were defined based on the modulation maps shown in Fig. S1A, S1C. In total, we found 9 cortical ROIs that showed modulation at overlapping or identical anatomical locations in both the ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres of both monkeys.

The 9 cortical ROIs for the hemisphere ipsilateral to the SC inactivation are illustrated in Fig. 4. The coronal slices show the anatomical location and attention-related modulation during control and neglect (as in Fig. 2), and the time-courses quantify the %change in BOLD for Attend and Ignore conditions during control and neglect. For each ROI, we also computed d-prime values (which capture effects on both the mean and variance of the BOLD signal) to summarize the attention-related modulation during control and neglect; the mean attention-related modulations (d’) and bootstrapped confidence intervals for both ipsilateral and contralateral ROIs during control and neglect are shown in the bar plots (Fig. 4). To identify the regions with significant changes, we then compared the modulation (d’) during control and neglect for ipsilateral and contralateral ROIs (bootstrap test; p<0.05). The rows in Fig. 4 present the ROIs rank-ordered by the size of the unilateral effect on attention-related modulation during midbrain-induced neglect.

sec.p: Consistent with the voxel-wise ANOVA results (Fig. 3), we found significant unilateral reductions in attention-related modulation across both monkeys in the ipsilateral mid-STS ROIs – aFST/IPa and TPO (Fig. 4A, 4B). The effect was specific to the hemisphere ipsilateral to SC inactivation – we did not find any reduction in modulation of the contralateral aFST/IPa and TPO. On the contrary, we found an increase in modulation of the contralateral aFST/IPa and TPO of monkey # 2, consistent with the observation that monkey #2 showed a modest increase in performance (6.6 %) for the ipsilateral stimulus in the Attend task (Fig. 1F). These results further strengthen our finding that the mid-STS regions show unilateral suppression of modulation during midbrain-induced neglect and highlight the strong link between mid-STS cortex and neglect.

We also found regions with significant changes in the frontal and parietal cortex. However, unilateral reduction in modulation was observed only in FEF. In the prefrontal cortex, FEF showed significant reduction in modulation ipsilateral to SC inactivation in both monkeys with no significant effect on the contralateral side (Fig. 4C). Another ROI in the prefrontal cortex showed a significant effect only in one monkey: there was a significant reduction in modulation of ipsilateral and contralateral vlPFC in monkey #1 but not in monkey #2 (Fig. 4D). In the parietal cortex, we found significant reduction in ipsilateral LIPd of both monkeys and contralateral LIPd of monkey #2 (Fig. 4E). In monkey #2, both ipsilateral and contralateral effects in LIPd were of equal magnitude, with no significant effect in LIPv (Fig. 4F).

There were also some changes in visual areas but the effects were not unilateral and were mixed across both monkeys. In ipsilateral MT, both monkeys showed significant reduction in modulation (Fig. 4G). However, we also found a significant but modest reduction in contralateral MT that was smaller compared to the reduction in ipsilateral MT. In V2v, both monkeys showed significant reductions in the ipsilateral ROI. However, Monkey #1 also showed a significant and larger reduction in contralateral V2v (Fig. 4H). In visual cortical ROI V1, we found a significant reduction in modulation ipsilateral to SC inactivation in one monkey (Fig. 4I).

Control analyses comparing attention-related modulation in different ROIs during neglect and saline sessions (see Supplemental Info, Fig. S4) further confirm that the temporal cortical regions – aFST/IPa and TPO, along with FEF in the prefrontal cortex showed a unilateral reduction in modulation during midbrain-induced neglect. We also verified that these findings were robust to the attention-related measure (d’) we used by computing another attention-related measure that is equivalent to the β coefficient of the term contrasting Attend and Ignore conditions – namely, the difference between mean BOLD in Attend and mean BOLD in Ignore (μA-μI). These findings taken together with the results from the voxel-wise analysis implicate for the first time a region in the macaque temporal cortex in visual hemi-neglect, in this case induced through inactivation of the SC.

sec.title: Effect in aFST/IPa region during neglect was not contingent on visual motion
sec.p: A possible explanation for the reduction of attention-related modulation in the aFST/IPa region of macaque temporal cortex during midbrain-induced neglect is that the aFST/IPa region is related to higher-order motion processing. This explanation is partially consistent with previous fMRI reports showing activations related to higher-order motion processing and object-related processing in similar parts of the mid-STS cortex (Nelissen et al., 2006). To test if the effect in the aFST/IPa region during neglect was contingent on visual motion, we performed fMRI in similar attention tasks with and without SC inactivation in monkey #1 using a non-motion stimulus. All the attention tasks were the same as before, except that the motion stimuli were replaced with white noise stimuli and motion-change detection was replaced with a second-order orientation detection (see Methods). In the Ignore task, the monkey monitored the fixation stimulus for a luminance-change and ignored the peripheral white noise distractor stimuli and the brief second-order (i.e., defined by contrast not luminance) orientation pulse (Fig. 5A). In the Attend task, the monkey monitored the peripheral white noise stimuli and detected the brief second-order orientation pulse (Fig. 5B). The SC inactivation and other methods were the same as described for the motion stimuli experiments (Fig. 1). We confirmed that SC inactivation significantly affected performance for the contralateral second-order orientation changes compared to the ipsilateral second-order orientation changes in the Attend task during all sessions (Fig. 5C; Chi-square proportion test; p<0.05). We collected 7 no-injection (824 blocks each for both the Ignore and Attend tasks) and 9 SC inactivation sessions (848 blocks each for both the Ignore and Attend tasks) which we refer to as control and midbrain-induced neglect sessions, respectively.

The white contour indicates the aFST/IPa region affected during neglect in the motion task and is the same as shown in Fig. 3C.

G)Coronal slice displays the anatomical location of affected aFST/IPa region in monkey # 1 in the second-order orientation task. The white cross-hair indicates voxel with peak attention-related modulation in aFST/IPa region during control.

sec.p: First, we determined if the aFST/IPa region showed attention-related modulation in the absence of visual motion by contrasting Attend and Ignore tasks in the control sessions (Bonferroni corrected; p<0.05). We found significant attention-related modulation in the aFST/IPa region (see black arrow in Fig. 5D), in addition to areas of posterior STS, IPS and the frontal cortex. The attention-related modulation in the second-order orientation task was sparser compared to that in the motion-change detection task, perhaps because the orientation stimulus lacked the continuous dynamic changes of the motion stimulus. These results show that the aFST/IPa region was modulated during covert visual attention even in the absence of visual motion.

Second, we determined if the attention-related modulation in aFST/IPa during the second-order orientation task was also changed during midbrain-induced neglect (Fig.5E), using the same voxel-wise ANOVA analysis described in the earlier section. The inflated map of the interaction term F-statistic in the ipsilateral STS of monkey #1 showed that the voxels most affected during neglect were once again identified in the mid-STS region at the border between anterior FST and posterior IPa (F (1, 23083) = -63.64; see white arrow in Fig. 5F). On the contrary, there was no effect in the contralateral mid-STS region during neglect (F (1, 23083) = 0.000419). Importantly, the affected voxels in the mid-STS (blue region in Fig. 5F) completely overlapped with the aFST/IPa region that was affected in the motion task (white contour in Fig. 5F). In fact,further localization of the affected voxels revealed the same lower part of the fundus in STS at the identical anterior-posterior location (compare Fig. 5G and Fig. 3E). These results show that the same voxels in the aFST/IPa region were affected during neglect in both the motion and second-order orientation tasks, demonstrating that the effect in aFST/IPa region during midbrain-induced neglect was not contingent on visual motion.

sec.title: The same aFST/IPa region was affected during neglect induced by FEF inactivation
sec.p: Is the selective involvement of the aFST/IPa region specific for midbrain-induced neglect, or would cortically induced neglect similarly reduce attention-related modulation in this mid-STS region? To address this, we inactivated the frontal eye fields (FEF) of the prefrontal cortex in separate experiments. Like the SC, FEF inactivation in macaques has previously been shown to lead to performance deficits akin to spatial neglect (Gregoriou et al., 2014; Monosov et al., 2011). We identified FEF in the anterior bank of the arcuate sulcus using microstimulation with currents of 40 μA to evoke saccades (Fig. 6A). For reversible inactivation, we injected 1-2 μl of muscimol and mapped the affected visual field using a visually guided saccade task (see Methods; Fig. 6B). The contralateral stimulus in the attention task (white circle) fully overlapped the portion of the visual field showing saccade deficits during FEF inactivation (blue region). We also confirmed that the muscimol effect lasted throughout the entire imaging session using the same methodology as described for SC inactivation and imaging (see Methods).

sec.p: Perceptual choices in the Attend task for contralateral motion-changes compared to ipsilateral motion-changes were not significantly affected during FEF inactivation. However, we did find a significant effect on the median response times for contralateral motion-changes compared to ipsilateral motion-changes (median RTcontra = 545 ms; RTipsi = 521 ms; Wilcoxon rank sum test; p<0.001). A similar comparison of median response times during control sessions did not show any significant effect (median RTcontra = 523 ms; RTipsi = 523 ms; Wilcoxon rank sum test; p=0.92). These results confirmed that prefrontal cortex causally affects performance in attention tasks akin to spatial neglect. Over all, we collected 7 no-injection (768 blocks each for both the Ignore and Attend tasks) and 7 inactivation sessions (736 blocks each for both the Ignore and Attend tasks), which we refer to as control and FEF-induced neglect sessions, respectively.

Before determining if aFST/IPa region was affected during FEF-induced neglect, we confirmed that the aFST/IPa region (see black arrow in Fig. 6C) showed significant attention-related modulation during control sessions in addition to other regions of STS, IPS, AS and PS (Fig. 6C), in agreement with the attention-related modulations observed previously in the same task (Fig. 2C). To determine the effect of FEF-induced neglect on the attention-related modulation throughout cortex (Fig. 6D), we performed the same voxel-wise ANOVA analysis as described in earlier section and the F-statistic of the interaction term for voxels in the ipsilateral STS is shown on the inflated cortical surface in Fig. 6D.

The voxels most affected during FEF-induced neglect were again found in the ipsilateral mid-STS region at the border between anterior FST and IPa (F (1, 21322) = -93; white arrow in Fig. 6E), with no significant effect in the contralateral mid-STS region (F (1, 21322) = 2.684). The affected region during FEF-induced neglect (blue region) fully overlapped with the affected region during midbrain-induced neglect (white contour). Further localization showed the affected region to be in the fundus of STS at a similar anterior-posterior location (compare Fig. 6F and Fig. 3F). These results show that the aFST/IPa region was affected not only during midbrain-induced neglect but also during neglect induced by FEF inactivation.

The effect in aFST/IPa region during FEF inactivation was weaker compared to the effect in aFST/IPa during SC inactivation (compare Fig. 3D and Fig. 6E). We suspect this was likely because of the difference in performance deficits in the attention tasks during FEF and SC inactivations. SC inactivation resulted in significant performance deficits whereas FEF inactivation yielded modest but significant reaction time effects. A stronger inactivation of FEF with a higher volume of muscimol might have yielded comparable deficits to SC inactivation. Regardless of the size of the effect in aFST/IPa during FEF inactivation, our results show that the aFST/IPa region was affected during neglect induced by both cortical and subcortical inactivation.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In humans, the anatomy of hemi-spatial neglect includes regions of the superior temporal cortex that are part of a network with frontal and parietal cortex and subcortical brain structures (Corbetta et al., 2005; Hillis, 2005; Karnath et al., 2005). However, temporal cortical regions linked to spatial neglect have not yet been identified in monkeys. In this study, we combined fMRI with and without hemi-spatial neglect induced by reversible inactivation of superior colliculus in monkeys performing a covert attention task and identified the strongest reduction in attention-related modulation during midbrain-induced neglect in the temporal cortex. Specifically, a contiguous cluster of voxels in the ipsilateral aFST/IPa region of the mid-STS showed a dramatic reduction in attention-related modulation during neglect, and this effect was not contingent on stimulus motion. Moreover, this reduction was accompanied by a modest but significant increase in the contralateral aFST/IPa region. In comparison, smaller unilateral reductions in modulation were observed in other ipsilateral regions of the cortex including FEF and part of area TPO. These findings, taken together with the performance deficits during neglect, demonstrate for the first time in monkeys a strong link between modulation in the mid-STS region of the temporal cortex and attention-related deficits associated with neglect.

sec.title: Possible pathways from superior colliculus to mid-STS cortex
sec.p: How does suppression of activity in superior colliculus have such a profound influence on the modulation in the aFST/IPa region of the mid-STS cortex? Among several tectofugal pathways (Benevento and Fallon, 1975; Partlow et al., 1977), we speculate two possible pathways through thalamus as the likely candidates for mediating these effects. The first is the pathway from the intermediate and deep layers of SC to medial pulvinar and the reciprocal connections between medial pulvinar and regions of the mid-STS cortex (Benevento and Standage, 1983; Burton and Jones, 1976; Yeterian and Pandya, 1989). The second is the pathway from the intermediate and deep layers of SC to FEF through mediodorsal thalamus (Benevento and Fallon, 1975), and FEF projections to regions of the mid-STS cortex (Stanton et al., 1995). The dramatic reduction in modulation in the aFST/IPa region compared to the FEF during midbrain-induced neglect suggests that the pathway through the medial pulvinar might have larger influence on the aFST/IPa region compared to the pathway through FEF.

sec.title: Priority maps in the subcortical and cortical areas causally affect the aFST/IPa region
sec.p: Superior colliculus activity represents spatial “priority maps” and suppression of this activity leads to robust performance deficits in attention tasks akin to neglect (Fecteau and Munoz, 2006; Lovejoy and Krauzlis, 2010). In addition to the SC, prefrontal cortex (FEF) is another brain structure that represents spatial “priority maps” and suppression of activity in FEF also leads to performance deficits akin to spatial neglect (Gregoriou et al., 2014; Monosov et al., 2011). Our results showed that attention-related BOLD modulation in the same aFST/IPa region was reduced when activity in SC or FEF was suppressed, demonstrating that these subcortical and cortical “priority maps” causally influence the aFST/IPa region. This finding is in agreement with previous fMRI reports that similar mid-STS regions are causally affected by manipulations in frontal and parietal areas FEF and LIP (Ekstrom et al., 2008; Wilke et al., 2012). In addition, these mid-STS regions are reciprocally connected with the dorsal and ventral stream areas. These results taken together with previous anatomical evidence suggest that the mid-STS regions (aFST/IPa and TPO) may combine spatial “priority maps” from the sensorimotor structures (SC, FEF, LIP) with the visual information from the dorsal and ventral stream areas (Boussaoud et al., 1990; Saleem et al., 2000).

sec.title: aFST/IPa region: a potential homolog of the human temporoparietal junction?
sec.p: In humans, temporal cortical regions including the temporoparietal junction (TPJ) and its neighboring superior temporal cortical areas play a crucial role in spatial neglect (Corbetta and Shulman, 2011; Karnath and Rorden, 2012), and are functionally connected to frontal and parietal areas (Corbetta et al., 2005). In macaques, similar mid-STS regions as identified in this study are functionally connected to the sensorimotor structures (SC, FEF, LIP) implicated in spatial attention and neglect (Ekstrom et al., 2008; Wilke et al., 2012). This functional dependence on sensorimotor structures raises an interesting possibility that these mid-STS regions in macaque are homologous to the areas of the superior temporal cortex associated with spatial neglect in the human. At the same time, a recent study comparing humans and monkeys in an attention task was unable to identify a functional homologue of TPJ in the macaque, and thus concluded the opposite – that the human TPJ likely evolved independently and is not a shared primate feature (Patel et al., 2015). Importantly, the authors suggested that the macaque might not be an adequate animal model to study mechanisms of spatial attention and neglect. Here, by demonstrating a prominent and focal area in the mid-STS region that is affected during neglect induced by both cortical and subcortical inactivation, our findings suggest the TPJ region in humans has a potential homologue in the macaques. Beyond the location in the temporal cortex, the causal dependence of the mid-STS region on activity in sensorimotor spatial “priority maps” (SC, FEF) is similar to the proposed link between temporal cortical regions of the ventral attention network and sensorimotor areas of the dorsal attention network in human neglect (Corbetta and Shulman, 2011). While homology is notoriously difficult to establish, these findings for the first time establish a functional link between the temporal cortex and hemi-spatial neglect in the macaque and offers a new bridge between human and nonhuman primate models of hemi-spatial neglect.

sec.title: aFST/IPa region could be polysensory and may play a role in target detection
sec.p: As far as we know, there is no electrophysiology data available to infer function from the properties of neurons in the aFST/IPa region we identified, although there is fMRI evidence that similar parts of the STS show motion-sensitivity as well as object-selectivity (Nelissen et al., 2006). Inspection of the electrophysiology literature for the neighboring cortical areas suggests that the aFST/IPa region closely corresponds to the middle part of the superior temporal polysensory (STP) region (Scalaidhe et al., 1995), and visual activity of neurons in the STP region depend on striate cortex and midbrain SC (Bruce et al., 1986). These previous findings taken together with our result that modulation in aFST/IPa region depends on midbrain activity suggest that the aFST/IPa region is likely to be a part of the STP region. Neurons in the caudal and rostral parts of the STP region respond to visual, auditory and somesthetic stimuli and exhibit not only unimodal but also bimodal and trimodal response properties (Bruce et al., 1981; Hikosaka et al., 1988). Neurons in the anterior (rostral) STP region are also selective for 3D structure from motion (Anderson and Siegel, 2005), similar to neurons in the middle part of area FST (Mysore et al., 2010). Importantly, STP lesions result in delayed detection of contralateral targets (Scalaidhe et al., 1995), and lesions in the dorsal bank and fundus of STS result in unilateral neglect (Luh et al., 1986; Watson et al., 1994). These observations from the overlapping and neighboring regions suggest that the aFST/IPa region is likely part of the previously described STP region that contains cells responsive to multi-modal stimulation and may play a role in target detection.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Using fMRI and reversible inactivation in monkeys performing attention tasks, we identified a novel brain region in the mid-STS cortex (aFST/IPa) to be the most affected brain region during neglect induced by subcortical and cortical inactivation, and we showed that this effect is not contingent on the specific visual feature used in the attention tasks. Our results demonstrate for the first time in monkeys a functional link between temporal cortex and neglect, thereby bridging the gap between human and macaque model of hemi-spatial neglect. Future experiments in the aFST/IPa region should address the neuronal responses and their modulation, at different epochs in the selective attention tasks, both before and during neglect, to better understand the functional link between aFST/IPa neuronal activity and neglect. Such experiments might also provide insights into why loss of activity from the midbrain SC, an evolutionarily ancient structure important for orienting movements, appears to especially affect this particular region of primate visual cortex, amongst the many neocortical areas that could have been affected.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: Two adult male rhesus monkeys (Macaca mulatta) weighing 7-9 kg participated in this study. All experimental protocols were approved by the National Eye Institute Animal Care and Use Committee and all procedures were performed in accordance with the United States Public Health Service policy on the humane care and use of laboratory animals. Under isoflurane and aseptic conditions, we surgically implanted plastic head-posts and electrophysiology chambers to access the SC and FEF. The SC chamber was angled 38°to the posterior of vertical and directed at the midline, 15 mm above and 1 mm posterior to the interaural line. The FEF chamber was angled 30°lateral of vertical and aimed at a point 18 mm lateral from the midline, 25 mm anterior to the interaural line.

sec.title: Experimental apparatus
sec.p: Monkeys were seated and head-fixed in a custom-built MR-safe chair with a joystick attached inside the chair. Before each imaging session, monkeys performed a visual guided saccade task inside a darkened booth. The saccade task was controlled using a modified version of PLDAPS (Eastman and Huk, 2012). Animals viewed visual stimuli from a distance of 48 cm that were displayed at 1920 x 1200 resolution (∼ 60° x 38°) and 100Hz frame-rate on a VIEWPixx display (VPixx Technologies, Saint-Bruno, QC Canada), controlled by a mid-2010 Mac Pro (Apple Inc., Cupertino, CA) running MATLAB (The Mathworks, Natick, MA) with the Psychophysics Toolbox extensions (Brainard, 1997; Kleiner et al., 2007; Pelli, 1997). Eye position was recorded using an EyeLink 1000 infrared eye-tracking system (SR Research Ltd., Ottowa, Ontario, Canada).

During each imaging session, monkeys performed attention tasks and visual guided saccade task inside the vertical scanner. Stimuli were back projected on to a screen placed inside the bore of the vertical scanner using an Epson projector controlled by a Windows 2007 machine running MATLAB R2012b (The Mathworks) with the psychophysics toolbox extensions (Brainard, 1997). The timing of the stimuli and events were controlled by a QNX system running QPCS. Monkey viewed the screen through a mirror placed in front at a 45°angle. The total viewing distance of the screen was 53 cm. Eye movements were acquired and monitored in the scanner using an iView system (Version 2.4, SensoMotoric Instruments). Eye signal was calibrated at the beginning of each session. Joystick presses and releases were detected by disruption of an optic-fiber transmission using a custom-built device. Joystick was calibrated once at the beginning of the experiments.

sec.title: Attention tasks: Motion-change detection
sec.p: In the scanner, both monkeys performed three behavioral tasks: Baseline, Ignore and Attend. In all tasks, monkeys initiated the trial by holding the joystick down and fixating the central fixation spot with a colored central cue on a grey background. Monkeys fixated for the entire duration of the trial with in a 2°fixation window. The color of the central cue indicated the trial condition. In Baseline and Ignore trials, the color of the central cue was black (Fig. 1A, 1B) and the relevant stimulus was the fixation stimulus. In Attend trials, the color of the central cue was red (Fig. 1C) and the relevant stimulus was the peripheral motion stimulus. The sequence of events in three different trial conditions are as follows.

In Baseline trials, following 0.5 s of fixation, the luminance of the fixation spot decreased during a variable delay of 1 – 3 s on the 65% of the trials. Monkeys reported the luminance change by releasing the joystick within 0.3 - 0.8 s to get a juice reward (Fig. 1A). A total of 8401 trails (4433 in Monkey #1 and 3968 in Monkey #2) were collected during control and 7484 trails (3667 in Monkey #1 and 3817 in Monkey #2) were collected during SC inactivation in both monkeys. We also collected 4446 trials during saline injection in monkey #1.

In Ignore trials, following 0.5 s of fixation, two random dot motion stimuli were presented on either side of fixation at 8°eccentricity (radius) and 10°above horizontal meridian (azimuth). During the variable delay of 1 – 3 s, the luminance of the fixation spot decreased on 65% of the trials. Independent of the fixation luminance change, one of the peripheral motion stimulus changed direction during the variable delay of 1 – 3 s on the 65% of the trials. Monkeys ignored the motion direction change and reported the luminance change by releasing the joystick within 0.3 - 0.8 s to get a juice reward (Fig. 1C). If the monkeys released the joystick for a motion direction change, the trial was aborted. A total of 9139 trails (4912 in Monkey #1 and 4227 in Monkey #2) were collected during control and 8240 trails (4083 in Monkey #1 and 4157 in Monkey #2) were collected during SC inactivation in both monkeys. We also collected 4913 trials during saline injection in monkey #1.

In Attend trials, following 0.5 s of fixation, two random dot motion stimuli were presented at the same stimulus location as in Ignore trials. One of the peripheral motion stimulus changed direction during the variable delay of 1 – 3 s on the 65% of the trials. Monkeys reported the motion-direction change by releasing the joystick within 0.3 - 0.8 s to get a juice reward (Fig. 1E). There was no fixation luminance change in Attend trials. A total of 8672 trails (4765 in Monkey #1 and 3907 in Monkey #2) were collected during control and 7742 trails (4026 in Monkey #1 and 3716 in Monkey #2) were collected during SC inactivation in both monkeys. We also collected 4794 trials during saline injection in monkey #1.
In all tasks, 35% of the trials were catch trials and monkeys hold the joystick down to get a juice reward.

sec.title: Random dot motion stimuli
sec.p: The random dot motion stimuli were circular patches of moving dots, with the direction of motion of each dot drawn from a normal distribution with a mean value (defined as the patch motion direction) at 30°above horizontal and a 16°standard deviation. The lifetime (10 frames, 100 ms), density (25 dots/°2/s), and speed of the dots (15 °/s) were held constant. The radius of the aperture was set to 3°. Luminance of each moving dot in the motion patches was 50 cd/m2. The change in direction of motion (Δ) was 1 ± 0.25 standard deviations for both monkeys across sessions.

sec.title: Fixation spot stimulus
sec.p: The size of the fixation spot was 0.23°and the size of the central cue was 0.35°. The background luminance of the screen was 14 cd/m2 and the luminance of the fixation spot was 50 cd/m2. The luminance change in fixation spot during Baseline and FA trials was 1-2 cd/m2 across sessions for both monkeys.

sec.title: Attention tasks: Orientation-pulse detection
sec.p: In addition to the motion-change detection task, monkey # 1 also performed a version of the attention tasks with orientation pulse stimuli instead of the random dot motion stimuli. The sequence of events in all three conditions (Baseline, Ignore, Attend) was kept the same as the motion-change detection version of the task. The onset of the motion stimuli was replaced with the onset of white noise stimuli, and the motion-direction change was replaced with a 0.5 s second-order orientation pulse (Fig. 5A, 5B). In the Attend condition, the monkey reported the orientation pulse by releasing the joystick within 0.3 - 0.8 s to get a juice reward (Fig. 5A), whereas in the Ignore condition, monkey ignored the orientation pulse and reported the luminance change in the fixation spot by releasing the joystick within 0.3 - 0.8 s to get a juice reward (Fig. 5B). In the Attend condition, a total of 3700 trails were collected during control and 2680 trails were collected during SC inactivation. In the Ignore condition, a total of 3752 trails were collected during control and 2698 trails were collected during SC inactivation.

The second-order orientation stimulus was generated by briefly (0.5 s) modulating the contrast of a white noise stimulus with a 2-dimensional sinusoid. The noise stimulus was 6° in diameter and consisted of checks each the size of a pixel with luminance values ranging from 8 – 84 cd/m2, and the 2-dimensional sinusoid had a spatial frequency of 0.7 cycles/deg, and its orientation was 90°. We refer to this as a second-order orientation stimulus, because the oriented grating briefly visible in the stimulus was due to the local differences in contrast, not luminance differences. The mean luminance (38 cd/m2) of the stimulus was constant throughout its presentation and was the same across every band in the oriented grating.

sec.title: Block Design
sec.p: Baseline, Ignore and Attend tasks were presented in a block design as shown in Fig. 1D. Each run started with a Baseline block which lasted for 10 s and was presented in every alternate block thereafter. Ignore and Attend blocks lasted for 20 s and were presented randomly between Baseline blocks. The number of Ignore and Attend blocks were balanced in a given run. Each run lasted 480s.

sec.title: Electrophysiology
sec.p: Locations for muscimol injections in the SC and FEF were identified by single-unit recording and electrical microstimulation. Single-unit activity was recorded using tungsten in glass-coated electrodes with impedances of 1-2 MOhm (Alpha Omega Co., Inc., Alpharetta, GA). Electrode position was controlled with a Narishige microdrive. The electrical signal was amplified and recorded online using the OmniPlex system (Plexon Inc., Dallas, Texas). Response fields and saccade-related movement fields were mapped by having the monkey perform the visually guided saccade task; we confirmed saccade-related activity consistent with the known activity patterns in the FEF or SC. Electrical microstimulation was also applied (70 ms train duration, 350 Hz, biphasic pulses with duration of 0.25 ms) to evoke saccades with currents (40 μA in FEF; 20 μA in SC) confirming that we were in the FEF or intermediate layers in SC (Bruce and Goldberg, 1985; Robinson, 1972). All candidate sites were first identified by neuronal recordings and electrical stimulation prior to the muscimol inactivation experiment; in some cases, the FEF or SC site was verified immediately prior to muscimol injection using the electrode placed within the injection cannula (Lovejoy and Krauzlis, 2010).

sec.title: Muscimol infusion
sec.p: Reversible inactivation of the intermediate layers of the SC (n = 27; monkey #1: 19, monkey #2: 8) and FEF (n = 7; monkey #2) were done by injecting muscimol (5 mg/ml). The amount of muscimol injected ranged from 0.3 – 0.5 μl in SC and 1 – 2 μl in FEF. Infusion was done using a custom-made apparatus modified from (Chen et al., 2001), with an injection pump at a rate of 0.5 μl in 10 mins. For saline controls in SC, 0.3 – 0.5 μl of saline was injected at the same location in the intermediate layers of the SC.

sec.title: Visually guided saccade task and mapping of affected visual field
sec.p: In the saccade task, each trial started with the monkeys fixating a small square stimulus (0.23°wide, 50 cd/m2) placed at the center of the visual display. After 500 ms of fixation, a second target (0.23°wide, 50 cd/m2) was presented at some other location in the visual display. Monkeys were required to maintain fixation until the central fixation stimulus was turned off, 1-2 seconds after the onset of the peripheral target. At that point, the monkeys should make a saccade to the second, peripheral target and fixate it for at least 500 ms in order to receive a reward. The eye position data were used to detect saccades and quantify saccade metrics offline using methods described previously (Madelain et al., 2005).

Before imaging, monkeys performed the saccade task outside the scanner and the location of the second target was systematically varied every trial in order to quantify the metrics of saccades to targets across the visual field. We quantified the impairments in saccade metrics during SC or FEF inactivation by measuring the difference in the peak velocity for saccades made to targets at different locations in the visual field before and during inactivation. The target locations where the peak velocities of the saccades were impaired identified the affected visual field (Fig. 1E, 6B). Data were collected beginning 30 minutes after the end of the muscimol infusion.

Inside the scanner, monkeys performed the saccade task every 8 minutes and the location of the second target was alternated each trial between contralateral and ipsilateral stimulus locations (radius: 8°; azimuth: 10°). The time course of muscimol effect was measured as a difference in the saccade latency to targets in the contralateral affected visual field compared to targets in the ipsilateral unaffected visual field (Fig. 1E). We measured the impairment on the saccade latency instead of peak velocity in the scanner because, the low sampling frequency of the eye tracker in the scanner limited the accurate measurement of peak velocities.

sec.title: fMRI data collection
sec.p: Anatomical and functional images were collected in a vertical magnet (4.7T, 60 cm vertical bore; Bruker Biospec) equipped with a Bruker S380 gradient coil. EPI volumes were acquired using a custom built transmit and 4-channel receive RF coil system (Rapid MR International). In each run, we collected 192 whole-brain EPI volumes at an isotropic voxel resolution of 1.5 mm and at a TR of 2.5 s.

sec.title: fMRI Analysis
sec.p: Preprocessing of the fMRI data was done using AFNI/SUMA software package (Cox, 1996). Raw images were converted to AFNI data format. EPI volumes in each run were slice-time corrected using 3dTshift, followed by correction for static magnetic field inhomogeneities using the PLACE algorithm (Xiang and Ye, 2007). All EPI volumes were motion-corrected using 3dvolreg and were registered to the session anatomical using 3dAllineate. To combine EPI data across multiple sessions for a given animal, all sessions for a given animal were registered to a template session. A high resolution anatomical of each monkey was registered to the corresponding template session anatomical to overlay functional results in monkey’s native space. To overlay D99 atlas boundaries on the functional results, D99 anatomical in AFNI was registered to each monkey’s native space (Reveley et al., 2017). Surface maps were generated for D99 anatomical in each monkey’s native space using CARET from a white matter segmentation mask (Van Essen et al., 2001). Surface maps of D99 in each monkey’s native space were viewed in SUMA overlaid with anatomical boundaries and functional results.

sec.title: Functional maps of attention-related modulation
sec.p: To identify voxels that were modulated by attention we performed a GLM analysis using 3dDeconvolve in AFNI. Attend and Ignore conditions were included as regressors of interest and Baseline condition, motion correction parameters were included as regressors of no interest (baseline model). To control for the effects caused by any differences during Attend and Ignore blocks in blinks (Wilcoxon rank sum test, p = 0.007 (Monkey # 1), p = 0.99 (Monkey # 2)), saccadic eye movements within the fixation window (Wilcoxon rank sum test, p < 0.0001 (Monkey # 1), p < 0.0001 (Monkey # 2)), rewards (Wilcoxon rank sum test, p < 0.0001 (Monkey # 1), p < 0.0001 (Monkey # 2)) and joystick movements (Wilcoxon rank sum test, p = 0.79 (Monkey # 1), p = 0.53 (Monkey # 2)), we included these factors as part of the regression model. Reward times, joystick event times (press and release), blink times and saccade times (left and right) were convolved with the hemodynamic impulse response function and were included as part of the baseline model. In the blocks of all three conditions for both monkeys, the median duration of fixation was above 85% of the block duration. Saccades within the fixation window (magnitude less than 1°) were detected using previously described methods (Madelain et al., 2005). T-scores contrasting Attend and Ignore conditions were projected on to the inflated maps to show voxels modulated by attention. All functional maps were thresholded (t-score > 5.02) to correct for multiple comparisons (p<0.05, Bonferroni correction).

sec.title: Functional regions of interest and attention-related modulation
sec.p: Functional regions of interest (ROIs) were identified based on the local maxima of the attention-related modulation map from the control sessions for each hemisphere using 3dExtrema in AFNI. The BOLD time-course for each Attend or Ignore block was computed as a % change in BOLD relative to the BOLD in Baseline block preceding it. For each ROI, an average time-course was constructed by pooling time-courses of all voxels within a 2mm radius around the local maxima across all blocks from all sessions. D-prime was computed for each ROI as a measure of attention-related modulation from the Attend and Ignore distributions of BOLD values taken from the TRs 2 – 8 of each block. Attend and Ignore distributions were constructed by pooling BOLD values across voxels in a given ROI and across blocks from different sessions. The mean and variance of the Attend and Ignore distributions were used to compute d-prime (d’) following equation 1. The source of the variance in the Attend and Ignore distributions came from pooling BOLD values across blocks, sessions and voxels in a given ROI.

sec.title: Voxel-wise ANOVA
sec.p: For each voxel, we performed ANOVA with two factors and two levels each – covert attention (Attend and Ignore conditions) and neglect (control and inactivation). The 2×2 factorial design for each voxel was based on the BOLD values taken from the TRs 2 – 8 of Attend and Ignore time courses extracted from the control and neglect sessions. F-statistic of the interaction term was projected onto the inflated maps to show the effect of inactivation on attention-related modulation. For every voxel, the sign of the difference in attention-related modulation between neglect and control (d’Neglectd’Control) was added to the F-statistic of the interaction term to differentiate the decrease in modulation from increase in modulation.

sec.title: Stimulus mapping experiment
sec.p: To identify voxels responding to foveal and peripheral stimuli locations, a flickering checker board stimulus (4 Hz) that had concentric rings of 2°width spanning up to 12°eccentricity was used. In foveal visual stimulation blocks, the checker board stimulus was masked everywhere except for the central 2°radius. In peripheral visual stimulation blocks, the checker board stimulus was masked everywhere except for the two eccentric stimulus locations used in the attention tasks. The foveal and peripheral stimulation blocks (20 s duration) were interleaved with fixation blocks (10 s duration). A total of 258 runs (150 in Monkey #1; 108 in Monkey # 2) were collected in both monkeys across 13 sessions. Functional maps showing peripheral and foveal voxels were created using the same methods as described for creating functional maps for the attention tasks.
